Secure Linear Aggregation Using Decentralized Threshold Additive Homomorphic Encryption For Federated Learning

Haibo Tian 11    Fangguo Zhang 11    Yunfeng Shao 22    Bingshuai Li Dr. Tian and Prof. Zhang were with the GuangDong Province Key Laboratory of Information Security Technology, School of Data and Computer Science, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, Guangdong, 510275, P. R. China e-mail: {tianhb, isszhfg}@mail.sysu.edu.cn. Dr. Shao and Dr. Li were with Huawei Noah’s Ark Lab. e-mail: {shaoyunfeng, libingshuai}@huawei.com. 22
Abstract

Secure linear aggregation is to linearly aggregate private inputs of different users with privacy protection. The server in a federated learning (FL) environment can fulfill any linear computation on private inputs of users through the secure linear aggregation. At present, based on pseudo-random number generator and one-time padding technique, one can efficiently compute the sum of user inputs in FL, but linear calculations of user inputs are not well supported. Based on decentralized threshold additive homomorphic encryption (DTAHE) schemes, this paper provides a secure linear aggregation protocol, which allows the server to multiply the user inputs by any coefficients and to sum them together, so that the server can build a full connected layer or a convolution layer on top of user inputs. The protocol adopts the framework of Bonawitz et al. to provide fault tolerance for user dropping out, and exploits a blockchain smart contract to encourage the server honest. The paper gives a security model, security proofs and a concrete lattice based DTAHE scheme for the protocol. It evaluates the communication and computation costs of known DTAHE construction methods. The evaluation shows that an elliptic curve based DTAHE is friendly to users and the lattice based version leads to a light computation on the server.

Keywords:
P

rivacy Protection, Secure Linear Aggregation, Additive Homomorphic Encryption, Smart Contract.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is intended to train better machine learning models on decentralized real-world data. The models then could be used to build more intelligent equipments for people, such as cars, wearable devices or browsers. McMahan et al. [1] proposed a well known FL protocol. The players in their protocol include users who owned data and a parameter server that aggregates model information of users. The protocol runs periodically. In each period, the parameter server randomly selects some users to upload their local model parameters, and averages the parameters to update a global learning model. A user in a period downloads the global learning model, feeds their local data, runs a deep learning network locally and gets updated local model parameters, the information of which is sent to the parameter server. In different periods the server may select different users, and within a period some of the selected users may drop out.

As real-world data are usually sensitive, an important problem in FL is data privacy. Although user data are not directly sent to the parameter server in FL, information of local model parameters may leak the raw data of users. Fredrikson et al. [2] show how to recover train samples from prediction results of a model. Rubaie and Chang [3] exploit feature vectors to reconstruct raw input data of a model. Chai et al. [4] show how to recover preferences of users by model gradient data. Bonawitz et al. [5] believe that recent updated local model parameters of a user may leak raw data of the user.

There are mainly two approaches to solve the data privacy problem in FL. One uses differential privacy and the other uses cryptographic tools. The work of Martin et al. [6] is an earlier report of the differential privacy approach. Wei et al. [7] point out a tradeoff between the convergence performance and privacy protection levels of the differential privacy method. For a fixed privacy protection level, the number of users increases, the convergence performance behaves better. However, if the number of users in each period is limited, one may use the cryptographic tools based approach. Bonawitz et al. [5] propose an elegant solution based on one-time padding and a secure pseudorandom generator.

To the best of our knowledge, the solution of Bonawitz et al. [5] is the only work suitable for the FL using cryptographic tools. They take the data privacy problem in FL as an secure aggregation problem. And they show some new requirements of a secure aggregation protocol for the FL. Except a security requirement, other requirements are as follow:

  1. 1.

    The protocol should operates on a high-dimensional vectors;

  2. 2.

    The protocol should tolerate users dropping out;

  3. 3.

    The protocol should be communication efficient even with a new set of uses on each period.

With these requirements, Bonawitz et al. [5] show that previous works are unsatisfactory which include some works based on homomorphic encryption schemes. In detail, they believe that solutions based on Paillier scheme [8, 9, 10, 11] are either computationally expensive or require additional trusted dealer, and solutions based on ElGamal scheme [12, 13, 14, 15] need a high expansion factor considering the size of the group elements and that of the model parameters.

Considering the development of the communication technology, we believe that a moderate expansion factor is acceptable and the functionality of a protocol is more important. Liu et al. [16] proposed a federated forest where a parameter server should find the maximal value of user inputs. Zhuo et al. [17] proposed a federated deep reinforcement learning model where a parameter server needs to build a multi-layer perception on user inputs. The users in these scenarios are usually not mobile users so that the communication cost is not the dominate factor. However, to protect the privacy of users, a sum only secure aggregation is not enough.

We provide a secure linear aggregation protocol to enrich the parameter server. It could naturally be used in the federated averaging algorithm [1] in the same way as the secure sum aggregation [5]. It also could be used in [17] to build a linear multi-layer perception to get a reinforcement learning model. It may be adapted in [16] with the homomorphic encryption [18] to find the maximal value of user inputs. For simplicity, the solution here is only based on decentralized threshold additive homomorphic encryption (DTAHE) schemes.

Currently, there are three known methods to construct a DTAHE scheme. The first method is to distribute many secret shares to a user. Bendlin and Damgård [19] proposed a threshold homomorphic encryption scheme in this way. It relies on secret sharing schemes with general access structure. Boneh et al. [20] proposed such a scheme based on secret sharing schemes constructed by a monotone formulae. The second method is to use a large modulus for coefficients of an element in a polynomial ring. Boneh et al. [20] propose to use Shamir secret sharing scheme in this way. The last method is to use the ElGamal encryption as a basic building tool [21]. We exclude the Paillier encryption based construction method since it is hard to produce a shared key pair in a distributed manner without a trusted dealer. According to our evaluation, in the secure linear aggregation protocol, the communication overhead of the first method is too high and the computation overhead of the third method is a bit high. The second method also has a drawback since a large modulus means a higher polynomial degree when the noise bound is fixed [22]. So we provide a new method to construct a DTAHE scheme with security proofs. It does not increase the modulus size and polynomial degree.

The secure linear aggregation protocol is against an active adversary [5]. An active adversary could corrupt a parameter server and ask t𝑡t users to decrypt a cipher of a target user. It is not easy to defend against the attack. Note that Bonawitz et al. [5] add a consistency check round to solve a similar problem in their protocol. However, even we add such a round, the problem still exists since the target user may have dropped out before the consistency check round. To solve the problem, we introduce a blockchain system. We design a smart contract to record ciphers of users and to check the evaluation process of the parameter server. If the parameter server deviates its expected behaviours in a period, the parameter server could be punished and the users in that period could get compensation.

There exists a lot of works to introduce a blockchain into the FL. A top complained problem in FL is the incentive of users to participate a learning process. Researchers propose blockchain enabled models [23, 24, 25, 26, 27] to give rewards to data owners. Basically, model initializer proposes model parameters and rewards in the blockchain, data owners choose their interested model to download the current model parameters, to train an updated model by their local private inputs and to update information of model parameters to the blockchain, and miners of the blockchain aggregate inputs of users to get a new global model parameter and rewards relevant users. Pokhrel and Choi [28] and Kim et al. [29] show some theoretical results about the performance of blockchain enabled FL considering the delays in a blockchain. A simulation result in [30] shows that the FL without a blockchain is most efficient. Another motivation to introduce a blockchain system to the FL is about the trustiness of a learning model. Sarpatwar et al. [31] propose to model and capture provenance of an overall learning process for verification. Awan et al. [32] propose to record data produced in a learning task in a blockchain for verification. We use a blockchain as a trusted third party to verify the behaviours of the parameter server. Since a verification process usually could be separated from a learning process, the FL and the blockchain could work at their own paces.

In summary, our contributions are as follows.

  • •

    We give a definition of DTAHE for FL and provide a basic linear aggregation protocol based on the definition. The basic protocol supports a parameter server to linearly operate ciphers of model parameters from different users.

  • •

    We provide a secure linear aggregation protocol against an active adversary with security model and proofs. It shows how to use a blockchain smart contract to help a secure linear aggregation protocol.

  • •

    We provides a new method to construct a lattice based instance of the DTAHE scheme with security proofs. Evaluations show that the DTAHE scheme leads to a lightweight computation on the server side.

2.2 Federated Learning

McMahan et al. [1] described the FL framework. We give a briefly review to see their federated averaging algorithm. As shown in Fig. 1, there is a parameter server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} and many users. S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} exchanges model parameters with users to collaboratively build a better learning model. The federated averaging algorithm runs periodically. In each period, S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} selects n𝑛n users randomly. In Fig. 1, we intended to show two periods with totally different users. Next we focus on a period e𝑒e where users in a set Uesubscript𝑈𝑒U_{e}.

The FL in a period is as follows.

  1. 1.

    A user u∈Ue𝑢subscript𝑈𝑒u\in U_{e} is activated to download the global parameters from the parameter server.

  2. 2.

    The user u𝑢u feeds their local data samples to get updated model parameters. And the parameters or their gradients ωusubscript𝜔𝑢\omega_{u} with the number of local data samples nusubscript𝑛𝑢n_{u} should be sent to S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}.

  3. 3.

    The parameter server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} compute the updated global model parameters ω=1∑u∈Uenu​∑u∈Uenu​ωu𝜔1subscript𝑢subscript𝑈𝑒subscript𝑛𝑢subscript𝑢subscript𝑈𝑒subscript𝑛𝑢subscript𝜔𝑢\omega=\frac{1}{\sum_{u\in U_{e}}n_{u}}\sum_{u\in U_{e}}n_{u}\omega_{u}.

The parameter server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} continues to randomly activate a set of users in the next period until the parameters ω𝜔\omega converge to that of the global optimal learning model.

Users could upload the nusubscript𝑛𝑢n_{u} together with ωusubscript𝜔𝑢\omega_{u} so that the server could get the value ∑u∈Uenusubscript𝑢subscript𝑈𝑒subscript𝑛𝑢\sum_{u\in U_{e}}n_{u} and compute the updated ω𝜔\omega. So a sum only aggregation is enough for the federated averaging algorithm. However, a parameter server may execute more computations in other federated learning models [16, 17], where a sum only aggregation is not enough.

2.3 The Model Of Secure Aggregation For FL

We adapt the notion of message-driven entities in [33] to the FL security model [5] to describe the participants in a FL scenario. A message-driven entity is initially invoked by an environment process. Each entity has their initial states. Once invoked, an entity waits for an activation that can happen for a message from the network or an environment process. On activation, the entity processes the incoming message or the arguments from a process with its current internal state, and generates a new internal state, outgoing messages and a cumulative output. Once an activation is completed, the entity waits for the next activation if it does not stop.

A protocol π𝜋\pi consists of a server side progress πSsubscript𝜋𝑆\pi_{S} and a client side progress πusubscript𝜋𝑢\pi_{u}. An FL process in S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} invokes πSsubscript𝜋𝑆\pi_{S}, which runs periodically until πSsubscript𝜋𝑆\pi_{S} is stopped by the FL process. In each period, πSsubscript𝜋𝑆\pi_{S} randomly selects a set of users U𝑈U and activates their client side progresses. A user u𝑢u should have voluntarily invoked their πusubscript𝜋𝑢\pi_{u} before S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} activates them. On activation, πusubscript𝜋𝑢\pi_{u} exchanges messages with πSsubscript𝜋𝑆\pi_{S} until πSsubscript𝜋𝑆\pi_{S} finishes a period or πusubscript𝜋𝑢\pi_{u} is stopped by the user. There may be some auxiliary entities for the security of the protocol π𝜋\pi. A common setup includes a certificate authority (CA) [5]. A C​A𝐶𝐴CA is invoked and runs permanently to receive certificate requests from users and issue certificates to users. In our protocol, we also introduce blockchain miners B​M𝐵𝑀BM. Miners are invoked to receive transactions from users and the server, and to execute smart contracts on commonly consented transactions.

The server and each user have a bi-directional secure channel between them. Practically, it reuses a transport layer secure channel established by FL processes. Users do not have direct links in the protocol π𝜋\pi. The communications of users are transferred by the server. Users and the C​A𝐶𝐴CA may exchange messages at an initial stage. When the protocol π𝜋\pi runs, the C​A𝐶𝐴CA could be offline. Blockchain miners usually have a point-to-point (P2P) network to deliver transactions and blocks. When a blockchain is used in π𝜋\pi, FL entities should have the ability to send and receive transactions to and from the P2P network.

An active adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could corrupt the server and users in π𝜋\pi. For each period, the number of corrupted parties is at most ncsubscript𝑛𝑐n_{c} [5]. When 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} corrupts an entity, it knows the internal states and long-term secrets of the entity, and controls all the behaviours of the entity from that point. Obviously, the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} could be corrupted to act as a malicious server. When 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} corrupts a user, it could send transactions on behalf of the user.

We does not allow an adversary to corrupt C​A𝐶𝐴CA or B​M𝐵𝑀BM since we do not try to model the security of a CA system or a blockchain system. We simply make assumptions about them:

  • •

    A transaction from a user or the server will be executed and recorded correctly by blockchain miners within a bounded delay.

  • •

    A certificate from a C​A𝐶𝐴CA proves the binding relation of a verification key and the real identity of a user.

We define G​Oπ,e,{S1}∪Ue,𝒜​(x→,r→)𝐺subscript𝑂𝜋𝑒subscript𝑆1subscript𝑈𝑒𝒜→𝑥→𝑟GO_{\pi,e,\{S_{1}\}\cup U_{e},\mathcal{A}}(\vec{x},\vec{r}) as a global output for π𝜋\pi in a period e𝑒e where x→={xS}∪{xu}u∈Ue→𝑥subscript𝑥𝑆subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑢𝑢subscript𝑈𝑒\vec{x}=\{x_{S}\}\cup\{x_{u}\}_{u\in U_{e}} denotes the inputs of the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} and the inputs of users in the set Uesubscript𝑈𝑒U_{e} of the period e𝑒e, and r→={r0,rS}∪{ru}u∈Ue→𝑟subscript𝑟0subscript𝑟𝑆subscriptsubscript𝑟𝑢𝑢subscript𝑈𝑒\vec{r}=\{r_{0},r_{S}\}\cup\{r_{u}\}_{u\in U_{e}} denotes the random inputs of the adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} and users in Uesubscript𝑈𝑒U_{e}. Definition 1

The security goal in [5] is input privacy of all uncorrupted users. Apparently, if the privacy of all users are protected, the privacy of a user is protected. If the privacy of each uncorrupted user in protected, the privacy of all uncorrupted users are protected. So the two definitions are equivalent.

2.4 DTAHE

Boneh et al. [20] give a definition of decentralized threshold fully homomorphic encryption (DTFHE). We refine it as a DTAHE definition for the FL scenario. A DTAHE scheme is a tuple of probabilistic polynomial time (PPT) algorithms DTAHE=(SetupDTAHE=(Setup, K​e​y​G​e​n𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛KeyGen, S​h​a​r​e𝑆ℎ𝑎𝑟𝑒Share, C​o​m​b​K​e​y𝐶𝑜𝑚𝑏𝐾𝑒𝑦CombKey, E​n​c𝐸𝑛𝑐Enc, E​v​a​l𝐸𝑣𝑎𝑙Eval, P​a​r​D​e​c𝑃𝑎𝑟𝐷𝑒𝑐ParDec, FinDec)FinDec).

  1. 1.

    S​e​t​u​p​(1λ)→p​a​r​m→𝑆𝑒𝑡𝑢𝑝superscript1𝜆𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚Setup(1^{\lambda})\rightarrow parm: It takes as input a security parameter λ𝜆\lambda, outputs system parameters p​a​r​m𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚parm.

  2. 2.

    K​e​y​G​e​n​(p​a​r​m)→(s​ku,p​ku)→𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚𝑠subscript𝑘𝑢𝑝subscript𝑘𝑢KeyGen(parm)\rightarrow(sk_{u},pk_{u}): It takes as input the system parameter p​a​r​m𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚parm to produce public and private keys for a user u𝑢u.

  3. 3.

    S​h​a​r​e​(p​a​r​m,{p​kv}v∈U\{u},t,s​ku)→{ev,u}v∈U\{u}→𝑆ℎ𝑎𝑟𝑒𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚subscript𝑝subscript𝑘𝑣𝑣\𝑈𝑢𝑡𝑠subscript𝑘𝑢subscriptsubscript𝑒𝑣𝑢𝑣\𝑈𝑢Share(parm,\{pk_{v}\}_{v\in U\backslash\{u\}},t,sk_{u})\rightarrow\{e_{v,u}\}_{v\in U\backslash\{u\}}: It takes as input the system parameter p​a​r​m𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚parm, public keys of users in a set U𝑈U excluding the user u𝑢u, a threshold value t𝑡t and private keys s​ku𝑠subscript𝑘𝑢sk_{u} of the user u𝑢u, to produce encrypted shares ev,usubscript𝑒𝑣𝑢e_{v,u} for each user v∈U\{u}𝑣\𝑈𝑢v\in U\backslash\{u\}.

  4. 4.

    C​o​m​b​K​e​y​(p​a​r​m,{p​ku}u∈U)→p​k→𝐶𝑜𝑚𝑏𝐾𝑒𝑦𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚subscript𝑝subscript𝑘𝑢𝑢𝑈𝑝𝑘CombKey(parm,\{pk_{u}\}_{u\in U})\rightarrow pk: It takes as input the system parameter p​a​r​m𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚parm, public keys of a set of users in U𝑈U, and produces an encryption key p​k𝑝𝑘pk.

  5. 5.

    E​n​c​(p​a​r​m,p​k,mu)→cu→𝐸𝑛𝑐𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚𝑝𝑘subscript𝑚𝑢subscript𝑐𝑢Enc(parm,pk,m_{u})\rightarrow c_{u}: It takes as input the system parameter p​a​r​m𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚parm, a public key p​k𝑝𝑘pk and a message musubscript𝑚𝑢m_{u} from a user u𝑢u, and produces a ciphertext cusubscript𝑐𝑢c_{u}.

  6. 6.

    E​v​a​l​(p​a​r​m,{cu}u∈U,{αu}u∈U)→c^→𝐸𝑣𝑎𝑙𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚subscriptsubscript𝑐𝑢𝑢𝑈subscriptsubscript𝛼𝑢𝑢𝑈^𝑐Eval(parm,\{c_{u}\}_{u\in U},\{\alpha_{u}\}_{u\in U})\rightarrow\hat{c}: It takes as the system parameter p​a​r​m𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚parm, ciphers {cu}u∈Usubscriptsubscript𝑐𝑢𝑢𝑈\{c_{u}\}_{u\in U} and coefficients {αu}u∈Usubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑢𝑢𝑈\{\alpha_{u}\}_{u\in U}, and produces an evaluated cipher c^=∑u∈Uαu⋅cu^𝑐subscript𝑢𝑈⋅subscript𝛼𝑢subscript𝑐𝑢\hat{c}=\sum_{u\in U}\alpha_{u}\cdot c_{u}.

  7. 7.

    P​a​r​D​e​c​(p​a​r​m,c^,{eu,v}v∈U)→m^u→𝑃𝑎𝑟𝐷𝑒𝑐𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚^𝑐subscriptsubscript𝑒𝑢𝑣𝑣𝑈subscript^𝑚𝑢ParDec(parm,\hat{c},\{e_{u,v}\}_{v\in U})\rightarrow\hat{m}_{u}: It takes as input the system parameter p​a​r​m𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚parm, the cipher c^^𝑐\hat{c}, and a set of encrypted shares {eu,v}v∈U\{u}subscriptsubscript𝑒𝑢𝑣𝑣\𝑈𝑢\{e_{u,v}\}_{v\in U\backslash\{u\}} to the user u𝑢u, and produces a partially decrypted value m^usubscript^𝑚𝑢\hat{m}_{u}.

  8. 8.

    F​i​n​D​e​c​(p​a​r​m,t,c^,{m^u}u∈V)→m→𝐹𝑖𝑛𝐷𝑒𝑐𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚𝑡^𝑐subscriptsubscript^𝑚𝑢𝑢𝑉𝑚FinDec(parm,t,\hat{c},\{\hat{m}_{u}\}_{u\in V})\rightarrow m: It takes as input the system parameter p​a​r​m𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚parm, the threshold value t𝑡t, the cipher c^^𝑐\hat{c} and partially decrypted ciphers {m^u}u∈Vsubscriptsubscript^𝑚𝑢𝑢𝑉\{\hat{m}_{u}\}_{u\in V} from users in a set V𝑉V with |V|≥t𝑉𝑡|V|\geq t, and produces a plaintext m𝑚m.

One could simply give an ElGamal based DTAHE instance following the constructions in [21], which justifies the correctness of the DTAHE definition.

2.5 DTAHE Model

We adapt the model of DTFHE in [20] for the DTAHE. The first definition is evaluation correctness.

Definition 2

(Evaluation Correctness). A DTAHE scheme for a set of users U𝑈U satisfies evaluation correctness if for all λ𝜆\lambda and t𝑡t, the following holds:

The second definition is sematic security. It captures the privacy of messages.

3 Secure Linear Aggregation Protocol

We provides two protocols in this section. The first is a basic protocol showing how to embed a DTAHE scheme to the secure aggregation framework in [5]. The second is the secure linear aggregation protocol against an active adversary.

3.1 A Basic Protocol

As shown in Fig. 2, initially a server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} runs p​a​r​m←S​e​t​u​p​(1λ)←𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚𝑆𝑒𝑡𝑢𝑝superscript1𝜆parm\leftarrow Setup(1^{\lambda}) to provide a system-wide parameters for all users, and each user runs (s​ku,p​ku)←K​e​y​G​e​n​(p​a​r​m)←𝑠subscript𝑘𝑢𝑝subscript𝑘𝑢𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚(sk_{u},pk_{u})\leftarrow KeyGen(parm) to produce their key pairs. The server and users then runs a four-round protocol π𝜋\pi with an agreed threshold value t𝑡t. We next focus on a period e𝑒e to show the protocol.

  1. 1.

    Round 1 (AdvertiseKeys). When a user u𝑢u is active, it packs a message as mu,1=(u,p​ku)subscript𝑚𝑢1𝑢𝑝subscript𝑘𝑢m_{u,1}=(u,pk_{u}) and sends the message to the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}. The user then waits for the first response from S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} or stops.

    The server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} makes a set Ue1=∅superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒1U_{e}^{1}=\emptyset. Remark 1

The basic protocol uses the framework in [5] to tolerate user dropping out. It needs the sever to be honest. A malicious server may simply return a cipher cusubscript𝑐𝑢c_{u} as mS,3subscript𝑚𝑆3m_{S,3} to decrypt the cipher.

3.2 The Secure Linear Aggregation Protocol

Bonawitz et al. [5] use a certificate authority (CA) and an extra consistency round to defend against an active adversary. We also use a CA but keep our protocol four rounds. We introduce a smart contract in a blockchain to encourage the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} and users to be honest.

The blockchain is described as σ→λt+1=Υ​(σ→λt,T​x)subscript→𝜎subscript𝜆𝑡1Υsubscript→𝜎subscript𝜆𝑡𝑇𝑥\vec{\sigma}_{\lambda_{t}+1}=\Upsilon(\vec{\sigma}_{\lambda_{t}},Tx) [34] where ΥΥ\Upsilon is a state transition function, σ→λtsubscript→𝜎subscript𝜆𝑡\vec{\sigma}_{\lambda_{t}} is the system state in a block height λtsubscript𝜆𝑡\lambda_{t}, and T​x𝑇𝑥Tx is a transaction in the system. A transaction could be described as

T​x=(f​r​o​m,t​o,v​a​l​u​e,d​a​t​a,a​u​x,s​i​g)𝑇𝑥𝑓𝑟𝑜𝑚𝑡𝑜𝑣𝑎𝑙𝑢𝑒𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎𝑎𝑢𝑥𝑠𝑖𝑔Tx=(from,to,value,data,aux,sig)

where f​r​o​m𝑓𝑟𝑜𝑚from and t​o𝑡𝑜to fields are the sender and receiver accounts of the transaction, v​a​l​u​e𝑣𝑎𝑙𝑢𝑒value field is the values to be transferred from the sender to the receiver, d​a​t​a𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎data field is arbitrary data of the sender, a​u​x𝑎𝑢𝑥aux field is the auxiliary information used in the blockchain and s​i​g𝑠𝑖𝑔sig field is the sender’s signature. The instance of the blockchain certainly could be the Ethereum [34]. Any other blockchain system supporting state transition is fine.

Initially, the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} has an account a​c​cS𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑆acc_{S} and a user u𝑢u has an account a​c​cu𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢acc_{u} in the blockchain. The server should deploy a smart contract E​n​c​C​h​e​c​k𝐸𝑛𝑐𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘EncCheck on the blockchain which will have an account a​c​cE𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝐸acc_{E} after deployment.

Definition 5

(E​n​c​C​h​e​c​k𝐸𝑛𝑐𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘EncCheck). The smart contract includes three functions. A function I​n​i​t𝐼𝑛𝑖𝑡Init is for the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} to deposit values and set parameters. A function R​e​c​o​r​d𝑅𝑒𝑐𝑜𝑟𝑑Record is for a user to record their encrypted inputs. A function C​h​e​c​k𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘Check is for the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} and users to check the correctness of a protocol transcript.

  • •

    I​n​i​t𝐼𝑛𝑖𝑡Init: If the transaction T​x𝑇𝑥Tx is signed by the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}, the d​a​t​a𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎data field of the transaction includes “I​n​i​t𝐼𝑛𝑖𝑡Init” as the function name, and a threshold value t𝑡t and the number of periods p​r​d​s𝑝𝑟𝑑𝑠prds supported by the contract as the arguments, the function checks a deposit variable D​e​p𝐷𝑒𝑝Dep of the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}. If D​e​p<M​i​n​V​a​l​u​e∗p​r​d​s𝐷𝑒𝑝𝑀𝑖𝑛𝑉𝑎𝑙𝑢𝑒𝑝𝑟𝑑𝑠Dep<MinValue*prds, it checks that D​e​p+v​a​l​u​e≥M​i​n​V​a​l​u​e∗p​r​d​s𝐷𝑒𝑝𝑣𝑎𝑙𝑢𝑒𝑀𝑖𝑛𝑉𝑎𝑙𝑢𝑒𝑝𝑟𝑑𝑠Dep+value\geq MinValue*prds where M​i​n​V​a​l​u​e𝑀𝑖𝑛𝑉𝑎𝑙𝑢𝑒MinValue is the smallest deposit value for a period. If the check fails, it stops. Otherwise, it transfers values from the server account to the contract account, and stores (a​c​cS,t,D​e​p,p​r​d​s)𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑆𝑡𝐷𝑒𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑑𝑠(acc_{S},t,Dep,prds) in the contract.

  • •

    R​e​c​o​r​d𝑅𝑒𝑐𝑜𝑟𝑑Record: If the d​a​t​a𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎data field of the transaction includes “R​e​c​o​r​d𝑅𝑒𝑐𝑜𝑟𝑑Record” as the function name, and an epoch session id e​s​i​du𝑒𝑠𝑖subscript𝑑𝑢esid_{u} and a cipher ca​c​cusubscript𝑐𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢c_{acc_{u}} as the arguments, the function stores (e​s​i​du,a​c​cu,ca​c​cu)𝑒𝑠𝑖subscript𝑑𝑢𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢subscript𝑐𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢(esid_{u},acc_{u},c_{acc_{u}}) in the contract.

  • •

    C​h​e​c​k𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘Check: If the transaction T​x𝑇𝑥Tx is singed by the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}, the d​a​t​a𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎data field of the transaction includes “C​h​e​c​k𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘Check” as the function name, and a termination flag d​r​a​w𝑑𝑟𝑎𝑤draw, an epoch session id e​s​i​dS𝑒𝑠𝑖subscript𝑑𝑆esid_{S}, a cipher cSsubscript𝑐𝑆c_{S}, a list of user accounts LAsubscript𝐿𝐴L_{A}, and coefficients {αa​c​cu}a​c​cu∈LAsubscriptsubscript𝛼𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢subscript𝐿𝐴\{\alpha_{acc_{u}}\}_{acc_{u}\in L_{A}} as the arguments, the function checks whether e​s​i​dS𝑒𝑠𝑖subscript𝑑𝑆esid_{S} is new. If the e​s​i​dS𝑒𝑠𝑖subscript𝑑𝑆esid_{S} is used before in another transaction T​x′𝑇superscript𝑥′Tx^{\prime}, it checks whether the two transactions are the same. If they are different, the check fails. If they are the same, the function stops. The function forms a set

    AA={a​c​cu:a​c​cu∈L​A∧e​s​i​du=e​s​i​dS}.subscript𝐴𝐴conditional-set𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢𝐿𝐴𝑒𝑠𝑖subscript𝑑𝑢𝑒𝑠𝑖subscript𝑑𝑆A_{A}=\{acc_{u}:acc_{u}\in LA\wedge esid_{u}=esid_{S}\}.

    If e​s​i​dS𝑒𝑠𝑖subscript𝑑𝑆esid_{S} is new, it checks that the size |AA|≥tsubscript𝐴𝐴𝑡|A_{A}|\geq t, and

    cS=E​v​a​l​(p​a​r​m,{ca​c​cu}a​c​cu∈AA,{αa​c​cu}a​c​cu∈AA).subscript𝑐𝑆𝐸𝑣𝑎𝑙𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚subscriptsubscript𝑐𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢subscript𝐴𝐴subscriptsubscript𝛼𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢subscript𝐴𝐴c_{S}=Eval(parm,\{c_{acc_{u}}\}_{acc_{u}\in A_{A}},\{\alpha_{acc_{u}}\}_{acc_{u}\in A_{A}}).

    If any check fails, the value M​i​n​V​a​l​u​e𝑀𝑖𝑛𝑉𝑎𝑙𝑢𝑒MinValue is shared by users in the AAsubscript𝐴𝐴A_{A} set. Otherwise, it updates p​r​d​s=p​r​d​s−1𝑝𝑟𝑑𝑠𝑝𝑟𝑑𝑠1prds=prds-1, and if d​r​a​w𝑑𝑟𝑎𝑤draw is t​r​u​e𝑡𝑟𝑢𝑒true, it transfers the deposit back to the account of the server after six new blocks. When the deposit is cleared, the contract suicides.

Now the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} has two tasks to initialize the protocol. At first, the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} runs p​a​r​m←S​e​t​u​p​(1λ)←𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚𝑆𝑒𝑡𝑢𝑝superscript1𝜆parm\leftarrow Setup(1^{\lambda}) to provide system-wide parameters for all users. Secondly, the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} produces a transaction as

T​xS,1=(a​c​cS,a​c​cE,v​a​l​u​e,I​n​i​t​‖t‖​p​r​d​s,a​u​x,s​i​g)𝑇subscript𝑥𝑆1𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑆𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝐸𝑣𝑎𝑙𝑢𝑒𝐼𝑛𝑖𝑡norm𝑡𝑝𝑟𝑑𝑠𝑎𝑢𝑥𝑠𝑖𝑔Tx_{S,1}=(acc_{S},acc_{E},value,Init||t||prds,aux,sig)

to initialize the deployed smart contract.

A user u𝑢u has three tasks to participate in the protocol II. At first, it runs (s​ku,p​ku)←K​e​y​G​e​n​(p​a​r​m)←𝑠subscript𝑘𝑢𝑝subscript𝑘𝑢𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚(sk_{u},pk_{u})\leftarrow KeyGen(parm) to produce protocol keys. Secondly, it produces a transaction

T​xu,1=(a​c​cu,a​c​cu,0,p​ku,a​u​x,s​i​g)𝑇subscript𝑥𝑢1𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢0𝑝subscript𝑘𝑢𝑎𝑢𝑥𝑠𝑖𝑔Tx_{u,1}=(acc_{u},acc_{u},0,pk_{u},aux,sig)

and sends the transaction to the blockchain to store its public keys. Thirdly, the user u𝑢u should produce a signature key pair (s​kS​i​g​u,v​kS​i​g​u)←S​I​G.G​e​n​(1λ)formulae-sequence←𝑠subscript𝑘𝑆𝑖𝑔𝑢𝑣subscript𝑘𝑆𝑖𝑔𝑢𝑆𝐼𝐺𝐺𝑒𝑛superscript1𝜆(sk_{Sigu},vk_{Sigu})\leftarrow SIG.Gen(1^{\lambda}) using a signature scheme (S​I​G.G​e​n,S​I​G.S​i​g​n,S​I​G.V​e​r)formulae-sequence𝑆𝐼𝐺𝐺𝑒𝑛𝑆𝐼𝐺𝑆𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑆𝐼𝐺𝑉𝑒𝑟(SIG.Gen,SIG.Sign,SIG.Ver) that is existential unforgeable against adaptive chosen messages (EUF-CMA). And then u𝑢u applies for a certificate c​e​r​tu𝑐𝑒𝑟subscript𝑡𝑢cert_{u} of the verifying key v​kS​i​g​u𝑣subscript𝑘𝑆𝑖𝑔𝑢vk_{Sigu} from a CA.

The CA and miners are auxiliary entities in the protocol. A CA is used to defend against a “Sybil” attack where an adversary may create many blockchain accounts to act as users. The miners of a blockchain receive transactions, pack them into blocks, reach a consensus on a block and update the global state. The public keys of users, parameters of the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}, and deposited values of the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} are states of the blockchain maintained by the miners. The whole picture of the protocol is in Fig. 3. We next focus on a period e𝑒e to show the protocol.

  1. 1.

    Round 1 (AdvertiseAccounts). When a user u𝑢u is active, it looks up the deposit D​e​p𝐷𝑒𝑝Dep, supported periods p​r​d​s𝑝𝑟𝑑𝑠prds and the threshold t𝑡t in the smart contract account a​c​cE𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝐸acc_{E} indexed by the server account a​c​cS𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑆acc_{S}. If D​e​p𝐷𝑒𝑝Dep, t𝑡t, or p​r​d​s𝑝𝑟𝑑𝑠prds are too small for the user’s local policy, the user simply stops. Otherwise, it produces a signature

    σu←SIG.Sign(skS​i​g​u,accu||Tu)\sigma_{u}\leftarrow SIG.Sign(sk_{Sigu},acc_{u}||T_{u})

    where Tusubscript𝑇𝑢T_{u} is a time stamp of the user. It packs a message as mu,1=(u,a​c​cu,Tu,σu,c​e​r​tu)subscript𝑚𝑢1𝑢𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢subscript𝑇𝑢subscript𝜎𝑢𝑐𝑒𝑟subscript𝑡𝑢m_{u,1}=(u,acc_{u},T_{u},\sigma_{u},cert_{u}) and sends the message to the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}.     The server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} builds a set Ue1superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒1U_{e}^{1} as in the basic protocol.   2. 2.

    Round 2 (ShareKeys). When a user u𝑢u receives mS,1subscript𝑚𝑆1m_{S,1}, it parses mS,1subscript𝑚𝑆1m_{S,1} to extract the identities of users which form a set Ue1superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒1U_{e}^{1}.     The server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} executes in the same way as in the basic protocol to produce mS,2,vsubscript𝑚𝑆2𝑣m_{S,2,v} for a user v𝑣v.

  3. 3.

    Round 3 (CipherCollection). When a user u𝑢u receives a message mS,2,usubscript𝑚𝑆2𝑢m_{S,2,u}, it makes a set Ue2superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒2U_{e}^{2} from mS,2,usubscript𝑚𝑆2𝑢m_{S,2,u}.     T​xu,2=(a​c​cu,a​c​cE,0,R​e​c​o​r​d​‖e​s​i​d‖​cu,a​u​x,s​i​g)𝑇subscript𝑥𝑢2𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝐸0𝑅𝑒𝑐𝑜𝑟𝑑norm𝑒𝑠𝑖𝑑subscript𝑐𝑢𝑎𝑢𝑥𝑠𝑖𝑔Tx_{u,2}=(acc_{u},acc_{E},0,Record||esid||c_{u},aux,sig)

    and sends the transaction to the blockchain. The user u𝑢u then waits for a response transaction of the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} from the blockchain network or stops.

    The server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} makes a set Ue3=∅superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒3U_{e}^{3}=\emptyset. After it receives a transaction T​xu,2𝑇subscript𝑥𝑢2Tx_{u,2}, if the transaction includes the same e​s​i​d𝑒𝑠𝑖𝑑esid as the current session number, S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} sets Ue3=Ue3∪{u}superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒3superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒3𝑢U_{e}^{3}=U_{e}^{3}\cup\{u\} where the identity u𝑢u is indexed by the a​c​cu𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢acc_{u}.     and packs a transaction

    and sends the transaction to the blockchain.

  4. 4.

    Round 4 (Decryption). When a user u𝑢u receives T​xS,2𝑇subscript𝑥𝑆2Tx_{S,2}, it builds a Ue3superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒3U_{e}^{3} set indexed by {a​c​cu}u∈Ue3subscript𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒3\{acc_{u}\}_{u\in U_{e}^{3}}.     The server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} executes in the same way as in the basic protocol to get an aggregated result.

When the FL process is to stop, S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} may send a T​xS,2𝑇subscript𝑥𝑆2Tx_{S,2} with the t​r​u​e𝑡𝑟𝑢𝑒true termination flag. The E​n​c​C​h​e​c​k𝐸𝑛𝑐𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘EncCheck contract will delay the withdraw action until six blocks are generated. This is intentionally for users to check the correctness of the server. Before the deposit is given back to the server, a user could send T​xS,2𝑇subscript𝑥𝑆2Tx_{S,2} received in an period to the contract. If there are different T​xS,2𝑇subscript𝑥𝑆2Tx_{S,2} transactions with the same e​s​i​d𝑒𝑠𝑖𝑑esid field, the deposit will be shared by users in that period.

Remark 2

In a period, two transactions are transferred by the blockchain network. Miners, the parameter server and users will receive transactions, parse them, and process them independently.

3.3 Security Analysis

We prove the security of the secure linear aggregation protocol against an active adversary. In a high level, we divide the global outputs into four views, and analyze the advantages of the adversary as a new view appears.

Theorem 3.1

Suppose that a DTAHE scheme is sematic and simulation secure, a signature scheme S​I​G𝑆𝐼𝐺SIG is EUF-CMA secure, and the secret sharing scheme in the DTAHE has a privacy property [20]. Let t𝑡t be the threshold value, ncsubscript𝑛𝑐n_{c} be the maximal number of corrupted users in a period, and λmsubscript𝜆𝑚\lambda_{m} be the minimal number of private inputs to make the final aggregated value hide one input. For any uncorrupted user u𝑢u, against an adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, if λm≥t−ncsubscript𝜆𝑚𝑡subscript𝑛𝑐\lambda_{m}\geq t-n_{c} and the deposit of the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} in the smart contract E​n​c​C​h​e​c​k𝐸𝑛𝑐𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘EncCheck has not lost, the protocol satisfies G​Oπ,e,{S1}∪Ue,𝒜​(x→)≈G​Oπ,e,{S1}∪Ue,𝒜​(x→′)𝐺subscript𝑂𝜋𝑒subscript𝑆1subscript𝑈𝑒𝒜→𝑥𝐺subscript𝑂𝜋𝑒subscript𝑆1subscript𝑈𝑒𝒜superscript→𝑥′GO_{\pi,e,\{S_{1}\}\cup U_{e},\mathcal{A}}(\vec{x})\approx GO_{\pi,e,\{S_{1}\}\cup U_{e},\mathcal{A}}(\vec{x}^{\prime}).

Proof: A global output G​Oπ,e,{S1}∪Ue,𝒜​(x→)𝐺subscript𝑂𝜋𝑒subscript𝑆1subscript𝑈𝑒𝒜→𝑥GO_{\pi,e,\{S_{1}\}\cup U_{e},\mathcal{A}}(\vec{x}) consists of four views {v​i​e​wi}i∈{1,…​4}subscript𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤𝑖𝑖1…4\{view_{i}\}_{i\in\{1,...4\}}. The v​i​e​w1𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤1view_{1} includes the outputs of the initialization procedures and the first round of the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} and users. The views {v​i​e​w2,v​i​e​w3,v​i​e​w4}𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤2𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤3𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤4\{view_{2},view_{3},view_{4}\} include the outputs of their corresponding rounds. We consider two global outputs G​O𝐺𝑂GO and G​O′𝐺superscript𝑂′GO^{\prime} with inputs x→→𝑥\vec{x} and x→′superscript→𝑥′\vec{x}^{\prime}. Note that the only difference of the two inputs are the inputs of the user u𝑢u. We denote the four views of G​O′𝐺superscript𝑂′GO^{\prime} as {v​i​e​wi′}i∈{1,…​4}subscript𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖′𝑖1…4\{view_{i}^{\prime}\}_{i\in\{1,...4\}}.

  • •

    Initially, v​i​e​w1𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤1view_{1} and v​i​e​w1′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤1′view_{1}^{\prime} include the same certificates, public keys and accounts in the initialization procedure of the protocol π𝜋\pi.

  • •

    When π𝜋\pi executes, v​i​e​w1𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤1view_{1} and v​i​e​w1′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤1′view_{1}^{\prime} include message-signature pairs of users and the first response of the server. v​i​e​w2𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤2view_{2} and v​i​e​w2′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤2′view_{2}^{\prime} include encrypted shares and the second response of the server. Since private inputs of the user u𝑢u are not involved, the two global outputs are indistinguishable until now.

  • •

    The v​i​e​w3𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤3view_{3} and v​i​e​w3′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤3′view_{3}^{\prime} consist of two kinds of transactions, separately. Transactions of users in Ue3superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒3U_{e}^{3} could form a ciphertext set {cu}u∈Ue3subscriptsubscript𝑐𝑢𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒3\{c_{u}\}_{u\in U_{e}^{3}}. The transaction of the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} includes c^^𝑐\hat{c}. In the v​i​e​w3𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤3view_{3}, the ciphertext of the target user u𝑢u is cu←E​n​c​(p​a​r​m,p​k,mu)←subscript𝑐𝑢𝐸𝑛𝑐𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚𝑝𝑘subscript𝑚𝑢c_{u}\leftarrow Enc(parm,pk,m_{u}), and the evaluated ciphertext of the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} is c^←E​v​a​l​(p​a​r​m,{cu}u∈Ue3,{αu}u∈Ue3)←^𝑐𝐸𝑣𝑎𝑙𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚subscriptsubscript𝑐𝑢𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒3subscriptsubscript𝛼𝑢𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒3\hat{c}\leftarrow Eval(parm,\{c_{u}\}_{u\in U_{e}^{3}},\{\alpha_{u}\}_{u\in U_{e}^{3}}). In the v​i​e​w3′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤3′view_{3}^{\prime}, the ciphertext of the target user u𝑢u is cu←E​n​c​(p​a​r​m,p​k,0)←subscript𝑐𝑢𝐸𝑛𝑐𝑝𝑎𝑟𝑚𝑝𝑘0c_{u}\leftarrow Enc(parm,pk,0), and the evaluated ciphertext of the server is produced in the same way. Now the chances of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} increases.

    • –

      𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could exploit the differences of the two views v​i​e​w3𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤3view_{3} and v​i​e​w3′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤3′view_{3}^{\prime}. Since the only difference is the message musubscript𝑚𝑢m_{u} and the message 00, if the DTAHE is sematic secure, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} has only negligible advantages to distinguish the two views.

    • –

      𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could exploit the combined views of v​i​e​w3∪v​i​e​w2𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤3𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤2view_{3}\cup view_{2} and v​i​e​w3′∪v​i​e​w2′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤3′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤2′view_{3}^{\prime}\cup view_{2}^{\prime}. Suppose that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could get the shared secrets in v​i​e​w2𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤2view_{2} and v​i​e​w2′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤2′view_{2}^{\prime}. Then 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could decrypt cusubscript𝑐𝑢c_{u} by the P​a​r​D​e​c𝑃𝑎𝑟𝐷𝑒𝑐ParDec and F​i​n​D​e​c𝐹𝑖𝑛𝐷𝑒𝑐FinDec algorithms. However, since the DTAHE is simulation secure, the secret shares are protected well. 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} has only negligible advantages to distinguish the two combined views.

    • –

      𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could exploit the combined views of v​i​e​w3∪v​i​e​w2∪v​i​e​w1𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤3𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤2𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤1view_{3}\cup view_{2}\cup view_{1} and v​i​e​w3′∪v​i​e​w2′∪v​i​e​w1′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤3′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤2′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤1′view_{3}^{\prime}\cup view_{2}^{\prime}\cup view_{1}^{\prime} in the two global outputs.

      At first, Suppose that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} corrupts users in C∗superscript𝐶C^{*} and |C∗|=ncsuperscript𝐶subscript𝑛𝑐|C^{*}|=n_{c}. It then knows secret keys {s​ku}u∈C∗subscript𝑠subscript𝑘𝑢𝑢superscript𝐶\{sk_{u}\}_{u\in C^{*}} which could be used to decrypt ciphers in v​i​e​w2𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤2view_{2}. The decrypted shares may help 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} to decrypt cusubscript𝑐𝑢c_{u}. However, since we assume nc<tsubscript𝑛𝑐𝑡n_{c}<t and the secret sharing scheme has a privacy property[20], this event happens negligibly.

      Secondly, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} may make special v​i​e​w1𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤1view_{1} and v​i​e​w1′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤1′view_{1}^{\prime}. 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could establish t𝑡t blockchain accounts and store public keys in each account. Then 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} acts as users to cheat the target user u𝑢u. However, since messages in v​i​e​w1𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤1view_{1} and v​i​e​w1′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤1′view_{1}^{\prime} are signed by users who have certificates from a CA, the accounts of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could not be identified by the user u𝑢u. And since we explicitly include a time stamp in the first message of a user, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could not replay messages of users in other periods. To satisfy the claims, the signature scheme S​I​G𝑆𝐼𝐺SIG should be EUF-CMA secure.

  • •

    v​i​e​w4𝑣𝑖𝑒subscript𝑤4view_{4} and v​i​e​w4′𝑣𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑤4′view_{4}^{\prime} consists of partially decrypted ciphers and the final aggregated value. 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} has more chances:

    • –

      𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could exploit the partially decrypted ciphers to discover secret shares. Since the DTAHE is simulation secure, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} has only negligible advantages.

    • –

      𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} could exploit the final aggregated value. An obvious strategy is that in the transaction of the server T​xS,2𝑇subscript𝑥𝑆2Tx_{S,2}, only cusubscript𝑐𝑢c_{u} is included. To make the strategy more practical, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} may aggregate some ciphers of corrupted users and the target user. Then the final output is the sum of nc+1subscript𝑛𝑐1n_{c}+1 inputs.

      The strategy is a possible way to get inputs of a user at the cost of the deposit in the smart contract. Since T​xS,2𝑇subscript𝑥𝑆2Tx_{S,2} comes from the blockchain network, miners will execute the C​h​e​c​k𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘Check function in the E​n​c​C​h​e​c​k𝐸𝑛𝑐𝐶ℎ𝑒𝑐𝑘EncCheck smart contract. The function takes {a​c​cu}u∈Ue3subscript𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑒3\{acc_{u}\}_{u\in U_{e}^{3}} as LAsubscript𝐿𝐴L_{A}, and checks the correctness of the evaluation of the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}. The smart contract builds a AA⊆LAsubscript𝐴𝐴subscript𝐿𝐴A_{A}\subseteq L_{A} and checks that |AA|≥tsubscript𝐴𝐴𝑡|A_{A}|\geq t. So if nc+1<tsubscript𝑛𝑐1𝑡n_{c}+1<t, the check fails and the server S1subscript𝑆1S_{1} will be punished. To avoid the punishment, 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} should prepare a LAsubscript𝐿𝐴L_{A} set with |LA|≥nc+λm≥tsubscript𝐿𝐴subscript𝑛𝑐subscript𝜆𝑚𝑡|L_{A}|\geq n_{c}+\lambda_{m}\geq t.

      𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} may try to withdraw their deposit before the penalty is paid. However, the smart contract needs extra six blocks to confirm the request of the server. The six-block waiting time is the last chance of users to check the behaviours of the server. Users are encouraged to send the received transaction of the server to the blockchain since they are the possible beneficiaries.

In summary, if the cryptographic primitives are secure, λm≥t−ncsubscript𝜆𝑚𝑡subscript𝑛𝑐\lambda_{m}\geq t-n_{c}, and the server pays no penalties, the adversary has only negligible advantage to distinguish the two outputs G​O𝐺𝑂GO and G​O′𝐺superscript𝑂′GO^{\prime}.

Remark 3

We explicitly introduce a parameter λmsubscript𝜆𝑚\lambda_{m} to describe the number of private inputs of uncorrupted users in a period. The parameter is in fact used in [5] implicitly. The consistency check round [5] makes sure that at least t𝑡t private inputs are summed. If ncsubscript𝑛𝑐n_{c} inputs are known by an adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, then in their protocol λm≥t−ncsubscript𝜆𝑚𝑡subscript𝑛𝑐\lambda_{m}\geq t-n_{c}.

4 A DTAHE Instance

Since all known construction methods of DTAHE schemes have some weaknesses. We provide a new construction method to produce a lattice based DTAHE scheme for an interactive protocol.

4.1 The Instance

We use the BFV scheme [22, 35] as a basic building block which is implemented in the SEAL library [36]. We need a sematic secure hybrid encryption scheme [37] HPKE=(HPKE.Gen,HPKE.Enc,HPKE.Ver)HPKE=(HPKE.Gen,HPKE.Enc,HPKE.Ver) to encrypt shares. A lattice based H​P​K​E𝐻𝑃𝐾𝐸HPKE instance will give us a fully lattice DHAHE instance that may be post quantum secure. We also need the Shamir secret sharing scheme denoted by SS=(SS.Split,SS.Recover)SS=(SS.Split,SS.Recover).

  1. 1.

Remark 4

If the data dimension of the message musubscript𝑚𝑢m_{u} is greater than d𝑑d, the number of noise samples e→u,2∈Rsubscript→𝑒𝑢2𝑅\vec{e}_{u,2}\in R increases.

4.2 Security Analysis

The security of our scheme could be reduced to a variant of the classical ring version decisional learning with errors (RLWE) problem [38, 22]. The variant is named n𝑛n-Decision-RLWE problem.

Definition 6

(n𝑛n-Decision-RLWE). For a random set {s→i∈Rh}i∈{1,…,n}subscriptsubscript→𝑠𝑖subscript𝑅ℎ𝑖1…𝑛\{\vec{s}_{i}\in R_{h}\}_{i\in\{1,\ldots,n\}} and a distribution χ𝜒\chi over R𝑅R, denote with A{s→i∈Rh}i∈{1,…,n},χ,μsubscript𝐴subscriptsubscript→𝑠𝑖subscript𝑅ℎ𝑖1…𝑛𝜒𝜇A_{\{\vec{s}_{i}\in R_{h}\}_{i\in\{1,\ldots,n\}},\chi,\mu} the distribution by choosing a uniformly random element a→←Rh←→𝑎subscript𝑅ℎ\vec{a}\leftarrow R_{h} and n𝑛n noise term {e→i←χ}i∈{1,…,n}subscript←subscript→𝑒𝑖𝜒𝑖1…𝑛\{\vec{e}_{i}\leftarrow\chi\}_{i\in\{1,\ldots,n\}} and outputting (a→,{[a→⋅s→i+e→i]h}i∈{1,…,n})→𝑎subscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]⋅→𝑎subscript→𝑠𝑖subscript→𝑒𝑖ℎ𝑖1…𝑛(\vec{a},\{[\vec{a}\cdot\vec{s}_{i}+\vec{e}_{i}]_{h}\}_{i\in\{1,\ldots,n\}}). The problem is then to distinguish between the distribution A{s→i∈Rh}i∈{1,…,n},χ,μsubscript𝐴subscriptsubscript→𝑠𝑖subscript𝑅ℎ𝑖1…𝑛𝜒𝜇A_{\{\vec{s}_{i}\in R_{h}\}_{i\in\{1,\ldots,n\}},\chi,\mu} and a uniform distribution μ𝜇\mu over Rhn+1superscriptsubscript𝑅ℎ𝑛1R_{h}^{n+1}.

By a hybrid argument, one could conclude that if an adversary has an advantage at least ϵn​-​R​L​W​Esubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛-𝑅𝐿𝑊𝐸\epsilon_{n\text{-}RLWE} to solve the n𝑛n-Decision-RLWE problem, the adversary has an advantage at least 1n​ϵn​-​R​L​W​E1𝑛subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑛-𝑅𝐿𝑊𝐸\frac{1}{n}\epsilon_{n\text{-}RLWE} to solve the classical RLWE problem in [38, 22].

If there is an adversary 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} with advantage ϵs​e​msubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑠𝑒𝑚\epsilon_{sem} to make the experiment E​x​p​t𝒜,S​e​m​(1λ)𝐸𝑥𝑝subscript𝑡𝒜𝑆𝑒𝑚superscript1𝜆Expt_{\mathcal{A},Sem}(1^{\lambda}) output 111, one could construct a challenger to break the n𝑛n-decision-RLWE problem with an advantage 12​ϵs​e​m12subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑠𝑒𝑚\frac{1}{2}\epsilon_{sem} under the condition that the secret sharing scheme S​S𝑆𝑆SS has the privacy property [20] and the hybrid encryption scheme H​P​K​E𝐻𝑃𝐾𝐸HPKE is sematic secure.

5 Performance

We evaluate the communication and computation costs of the secure linear aggregation protocol.

5.1 Communication

We have stated that there are mainly three methods [21, 19, 20] to construct a DTAHE. We concrete the method in [21] based on an elliptic curve version ElGamal (EC-ElGamal) scheme, and other methods based on the BFV [35, 13] scheme. The user side communication overhead of the secure linear aggregation protocol is calculated as follows:

∑i∈{1,…,4}mu,i=(n+2)​|u|+(n−1)​|ev,u|+|cu|+|m^u|+3​|a​c​cu|+|Tu|+|σu|+|S​i​g|+|c​e​r​tu|+|a​u​x|+|R​e​c​o​r​d|+|e​s​i​d|subscript𝑖1…4subscript𝑚𝑢𝑖𝑛2𝑢𝑛1subscript𝑒𝑣𝑢subscript𝑐𝑢subscript^𝑚𝑢3𝑎𝑐subscript𝑐𝑢subscript𝑇𝑢subscript𝜎𝑢𝑆𝑖𝑔𝑐𝑒𝑟subscript𝑡𝑢𝑎𝑢𝑥𝑅𝑒𝑐𝑜𝑟𝑑𝑒𝑠𝑖𝑑\begin{split}\sum_{i\in\{1,\ldots,4\}}m_{u,i}&=(n+2)|u|+(n-1)|e_{v,u}|+|c_{u}|\\ &+|\hat{m}_{u}|+3|acc_{u}|+|T_{u}|+|\sigma_{u}|+|Sig|\\ &+|cert_{u}|+|aux|+|Record|+|esid|\end{split} (8)

where n𝑛n is the number of users. Table I shows the main components in the equation (8). The security parameter λ𝜆\lambda is 128128128. An element in EC-ElGamal takes 333333 bytes where one byte is for y𝑦y-coordinate. L​R𝐿𝑅LR denotes the size of a ring element in Rhsubscript𝑅ℎR_{h}, S​N𝑆𝑁SN the number of shares to each user and L​N𝐿𝑁LN the number of ciphers to encrypt the user input musubscript𝑚𝑢m_{u}. L​R′𝐿superscript𝑅′LR^{\prime} and L​N′𝐿superscript𝑁′LN^{\prime} have the same meaning as L​R𝐿𝑅LR and L​N𝐿𝑁LN with L​R≠L​R′𝐿𝑅𝐿superscript𝑅′LR\neq LR^{\prime} and L​N≠L​N′𝐿𝑁𝐿superscript𝑁′LN\neq LN^{\prime}. The method to use Shamir secret sharing in [20] is denoted as BGGJK-2, and the other is denoted as BGGJK-1.

Fig. 4 shows the main communication overhead of the protocol on user side with different DTAHE constructions when the number of user increases. We mainly consider the components in Table I. We set |mu|=105subscript𝑚𝑢superscript105|m_{u}|=10^{5} for all instances, and set d=2048𝑑2048d=2048 and |h|=54ℎ54|h|=54 so that L​R=d∗|h|/8=13824𝐿𝑅𝑑ℎ813824LR=d*|h|/8=13824 bytes and L​N=⌈|mu|/d⌉=49𝐿𝑁subscript𝑚𝑢𝑑49LN=\lceil|m_{u}|/d\rceil=49. We set t=⌈n∗2/3⌉𝑡𝑛23t=\lceil n*2/3\rceil and compute S​N=(n−1t−1)𝑆𝑁𝑛1𝑡1SN=\left(\begin{array}[]{l}n-1\\ t-1\end{array}\right). The values of L​R′𝐿superscript𝑅′LR^{\prime} and L​N′𝐿superscript𝑁′LN^{\prime} are relative to the number of users since the noise element in the P​a​r​D​e​c𝑃𝑎𝑟𝐷𝑒𝑐ParDec algorithm should be multiplied by (n!)2superscript𝑛2(n!)^{2}, which are limited by the Theorem 4.1 and the equation (6) in [22].

From Fig. 4, we exclude the BD[19] and BGGJK-1[20] methods to distribute many shares to a user. Our method is better than the BGGJK-2[20] when the user number is greater than 262626. The EC-ElGamal method has the best communication performance when the number of users is greater than 202020.

5.2 Computation

Since the computation costs of the protocol are dominated by a DTAHE scheme. We give Table II to show the time cost of some DTAHE algorithms. We set the user number as n=35𝑛35n=35 and implement three DTAHE schemes for comparison. The schemes are implemented in Python. The “pyOpenSSL” is used to implement the EC-ElGamal based DTAHE. The small discrete logarithm of a group element is found by the well-known “Baby-Step-Giant-Step” method. An open source library “bfv-python” is adapted to implement our scheme and the BGGJK-2 method in [20]. For simplicity, we use a public python module “eciespy” as an instance of the H​P​K​E𝐻𝑃𝐾𝐸HPKE scheme. The CPUs are Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-8550U (1.80GHz, 1.99GHz) and the RAM is 16GB.

We use the “secp256r1” curve as the parameter set to implement the EC-ElGamal based DTAHE. For the security parameter λ=128𝜆128\lambda=128, we set d=2048𝑑2048d=2048, |h|=54ℎ54|h|=54 and |l|=17𝑙17|l|=17 for our DTAHE scheme. When n=35𝑛35n=35, the scheme constructed by the BGGJK-2 method in [20] requires |h|≥426ℎ426|h|\geq 426. So we set d=16384𝑑16384d=16384 according to the parameter table in [39]. Each data element in musubscript𝑚𝑢m_{u} in our test occupies 888 bits. The time costs of the three implementations are listed in the table II, which are measured in seconds. Apparently, a secure linear aggregation protocol with the EC-ElGamal based DTAHE takes the least time on user side. The protocol with our DTAHE scheme takes the least time on server side.

6 Conclusion

This paper shows a secure linear protocol mainly for complex federated learning models. When the communication cost is not the dominate factor, the protocol could be deployed in a federated learning model to protect the private inputs of users. The DTAHE schemes in the protocol may be further optimized to reduce the computation time. For example, parallel computing technologies may reduce the time cost of the EC-ElGamal based DTAHE, and multi-secret sharing schemes may reduce the communication and computation costs of our DTAHE scheme.
